Many small evolutionary steps add up to large evolutionary differences. Once you accept that evolution can occur in small ways, it logically follows that given sufficient time, differences in different populations will eventually be immense.
 
 Creationists typically avoid this conclusion by refusing to define macroevolution, or defining it and then redefining it when it suits them. They may first say that macroevolution is when a species evolves into a different species (and species is again poorly defined), and when this is demonstrated, they demand evidence something has evolved from one "kind" into another, a "kind" being completely undefined.
 
 Basically they want to see a monkey evolve into a dinosaur. Scientists will agree this has not occurred, and is unlikely to in future, but so what? Monkeys turning into dinosaurs, or chickens into pigs is not what any theory of evolution claims in the first place.

First things first,your understanding of microevolution is somewhat flawed. Nothing "adapts to" biologically, it can't. However, tiny changes happen in our genomes, and the results, while mostly harmful (cancers, genetic defects, people born without an anus,...) sometimes mean that one in a million is actually better - accidentally immune to a new disease, has more skin between the fingers and can thus swim better,...
 
 Humanity is a bad example for physical evolution. We have practically eliminated it, as we face no pressures. Take people who are born with webbed fingers. In theory, they should prosper in maritime environments. In practice, we consider them freaks. Now, imagine that as part of the global warming, a whole community gets flooded and a great deal of the people die - here, the mutants' increased survivability against strong currents, and the ability to hunt better suddenly outweigh the previous disadvantages - inability to hold agricultural implements properly or type fast.
 
 BTW, humans are evolving socially, though. People with better people skills are better at getting girls, smarter people get richer and attract trophy wives, etc. Oh, some change may be for the bad - our fascination with slimness goes for people who store less fat from food (insofar as biology is concerned), which is a bad thing come famine.

 I want to comment on this post from Zephyr. First of all, there are four important clues about our ape ancestry that come from comparing the genomes of chimpanzees & humans:
 1) now that that the chimp genome has been sequenced, it is a fact that 96% of their genes are identical to ours.
 2) chimps share the same ERVs (Endigenous Retro-Viruses) in their genomes as we do, in exactly the same position as they are in us, alluding to the same common ancestors who had originally contracted these viral infections.
 3) The GULO gene for endogenous synthesis of vitamin C is inactivated in both the chimp & human, but it is active in nearly every non-primate mammal.
 4) the human genome has 23 pairs of chromosomes, instead of the 24 pair found in all the great apes, because two of the ape chromosomes have fused, as evidenced by the presence of repeating segments of their telomeres (ends of chromosomes) where they were attached to eachother.
 
 The fossil record is much more involved than I have space to discuss, and the main sequence from Australopithecines to Homo habilis to Homo erectus to Homo sapiens is familiar enough to most people on these forums. There is no serious doubt that Australopithecines were fully erect and could walk bipedally, as evidenced by a very human-like pelvis, femur (thigh bone), knee joint and foot (without an opposing big toe). This first step toward humanity @ 4 million years ago is well documented with dozens of specimens. Hundreds of other specimens document the gradual transition toward a more human upper torso and skull over the next 4 million years.  This is true. Creationists, of course, are forced to make this bogus distinction, as the changes they call micro-evolution can hardly be denied, whilst what they call macro-evolution is the thing they are compelled to deny with every breath they take.
 
 In the real world degrees of evolutionary change form a continuum, from point mutations conferring, say, antibiotic resistance on a bacterium, to full-scale genetic isolation and speciation. There is nowhere a sharp cut-off between qualitatively distinct levels of change. (In fact one of the major difficulties faced by creationists is explaining just what kind of mechanism would, in their view, enforce such a cut-off.)

"Macroevolution" and "microevolution" are real terms that are used, or have been used, in evolutionary biology. As I recall, the first term used was macroevolution and it was coined by Richard Goldschmidt in 1940. He used it in reference to his hypothesis of species formation. Goldschmidt thought that species formed in a single step by one large mutation. The hypothesis is sometimes known as the hopeful monster theory. However, genetic studies have shown that Goldschmidt was wrong. Speciation by means of the accumulation of small genetic differences has been observed.
 
 Now that Goldschmidt's hypothesis has been rejected the terms are still used from time to time. Futuyma uses the word infrequently, mostly in discussion of the history of evolutionary theory. In the introduction to Part II of Evolutionary Biology: Third Edition he tells us that the next 4 chapters deal with the history of macroevolution. He defines it as the origin of higher taxa, and of their characteristics and distribution, throughout the long history of life. But in those 4 chapters, Futuyma doesn't even use the word macroevolution.
 
 He returns to macroevolution in Part V, where he again defines it in almost the exact words as above. The title of Part V is Macroevolution: Evolution above the Species Level.
 
 So yes, the two words are legitimate biological terms. However, they actually aren't used very much in practice. Biologists usually just talk about evolution and by context they know whether macro or microevolution are being discussed.
 
 Creationists like to pretend that macroevolution is somewhat like Goldschmidt's hypothesis, a cat giving birth to a dog or a gorilla becoming a man. It's really a bit of a straw man from creationists. The intelligent creationists know it and don't care if they make the ignorant creationists look like fools. It comes from arguing about evolution without learning what it is.

At the DNA level, the human and chimpanzee genomes are almost 99% identical at the DNA bases where the two genomes align to each other. By taking into account the insertions and deletions that have occurred in each species since their divergence from a common ancestor ~5 to 6 million years ago, they still share 96% of their sequence. At the protein level, 29% of proteins have the identical sequence and the average protein has accumulated just one human-specific amino-acid change. ["In fact, the typical human protein has accumulated just one unique change since chimpanzees and humans diverged from a common ancestor about 6 million years ago."] To put this into perspective, the number of genetic differences between human and chimpanzee is approximately 10 times less than the number of differences found between the previously sequenced genomes of mouse and rat. The results provide a strong support for Darwin's 1871 conclusion that humanity's closest relatives are the African apes; it is an example of a testable prediction about evolution - made even before the discovery of DNA's role in heredity - that is confirmed by experiment.
